Type Forge
  • type_forge.validators
  • View page source

type_forge.validators

This module initializes the validators submodule of the type_forge package.

It provides a centralized interface for importing various validators, allowing for modular design and easy access to validation functionalities.

Available Validators: - Basic Validators - Composite Validators - Validator Factory

Submodules

  • type_forge.validators.basic
  • type_forge.validators.composite
  • type_forge.validators.factory

Attributes

DictSchemaT

Dictionary schema mapping string keys to schema types.

ParentSpecType

Parent class specification supporting single class or tuple of classes.

SchemaTypeT

A schema type definition that can recursively represent any data structure.

Check if a collection has a valid length.

Package Contents

class type_forge.validators.BaseValidator[source]

Base class for all validators in the type_forge framework.

Provides the fundamental validation interface that all validators must implement, with support for both simple boolean validation and detailed validation results.

Validators form the core of the type forge validation process, each implementing specific validation logic while adhering to a common interface that enables composition and chaining. This follows the “Composition Over Inheritance” principle from Eidosian design.

The class follows the Template Method pattern, providing a default implementation of validate_with_detail that builds upon the abstract validate method that subclasses must implement.

validate(value)[source]

Validate the given value.

This is the simplified validation interface that returns only a boolean result. Subclasses must implement this method to define specific validation logic.

Parameters:

value (object) – The value to validate

Returns:

True if the value is valid, False otherwise

Return type:

bool

Raises:

NotImplementedError – If the subclass doesn’t implement this method

validate_with_detail(value)[source]

Validate the given value with detailed results.

Provides comprehensive validation information including specific violations and an optionally converted value. This implementation relies on the simple validate method, but subclasses may override for more detailed reporting.

This method demonstrates the recursive refinement principle by building detailed validation upon the simpler boolean validation. It also implements the “Errors as Values” principle by encapsulating failures in the return type rather than through exceptions.

Parameters:

value (object) – The value to validate

Returns:

Detailed validation results with type preservation

Return type:

ValidationResult[object]

Raises:

  • No direct exceptions, but captures exceptions from validate() and –

  • converts them to ValidationResult with appropriate violations –

class type_forge.validators.BaseValidator[source]

Base class for all validators in the type_forge framework.

Provides the fundamental validation interface that all validators must implement, with support for both simple boolean validation and detailed validation results.

Validators form the core of the type forge validation process, each implementing specific validation logic while adhering to a common interface that enables composition and chaining. This follows the “Composition Over Inheritance” principle from Eidosian design.

The class follows the Template Method pattern, providing a default implementation of validate_with_detail that builds upon the abstract validate method that subclasses must implement.

static validate_dict(value, key_type, value_type)[source]

Validate that the value is a dictionary with specific key and value types.

Parameters:

  • key_type (Type[T]) – The expected type of keys in the dictionary

Returns:

The validated dictionary

Raises:

ValueError – If the value is not a dictionary or contains keys/values of the wrong type

Return type:

Dict[T, S]

class type_forge.validators.SupportsBoolConversion[source]

Bases: Protocol

Protocol for types that can be converted to bool.

This protocol defines the interface for objects that support conversion to boolean values through the __bool__ method.

Examples

>>> class CustomBoolean:
...     def __init__(self, value: bool) -> None:
...         self.value = value
...     def __bool__(self) -> bool:
...         return self.value
>>> bool(CustomBoolean(True))  # True
__bool__()[source]

Convert to boolean.

Returns:

Boolean representation of the object.

Return type:

bool

class type_forge.validators.SupportsFloat[source]

Bases: Protocol

Protocol for objects that support conversion to float.

__float__()[source]
Return type:

float

class type_forge.validators.SupportsFloatConversion[source]

Bases: Protocol

Protocol for types that can be converted to float.

This protocol defines the interface for objects that support conversion to floating-point values through the __float__ method.

Examples

>>> class CustomFloat:
...     def __init__(self, value: float) -> None:
...         self.value = value
...     def __float__(self) -> float:
...         return self.value
>>> float(CustomFloat(3.14))  # 3.14
__float__()[source]

Convert to float.

Returns:

Floating-point representation of the object.

Return type:

float

class type_forge.validators.SupportsInt[source]

Bases: Protocol

Protocol for objects that support conversion to int.

__int__()[source]
Return type:

int

class type_forge.validators.SupportsIntConversion[source]

Bases: Protocol

Protocol for types that can be converted to int.

This protocol defines the interface for objects that support conversion to integer values through the __int__ method.

Examples

>>> class CustomInteger:
...     def __init__(self, value: int) -> None:
...         self.value = value
...     def __int__(self) -> int:
...         return self.value
>>> isinstance(CustomInteger(42), SupportsIntConversion)  # True at runtime
__int__()[source]

Convert to integer.

Returns:

Integer representation of the object.

Return type:

int

class type_forge.validators.TypeViolation[source]

Immutable record of a type violation with path tracking.

Provides a structured representation of a type violation with context information for precise error reporting and diagnosis. The frozen dataclass ensures immutability for safer error handling.

Attributes

path: JSON path to the location of the violation. expected: Description of expected type or value. found: Description of actual type or value found. kind: Category of violation from TypeViolationKind.

Examples

```python violation = TypeViolation(

path=”user.address.zipcode”, expected=”string of 5 digits”, found=“‘ABC123’”, kind=TypeViolationKind.INVALID_VALUE

)

__str__()[source]

Generate human-readable representation of the violation.

Returns:

Formatted string with violation details including path, expected value, found value, and violation kind.

Return type:

str

expected: str
found: str
kind: TypeViolationKind
path: str
class type_forge.validators.TypeViolation[source]

Immutable record of a type violation with path tracking.

Provides a structured representation of a type violation with context information for precise error reporting and diagnosis. The frozen dataclass ensures immutability for safer error handling.

Attributes

path: JSON path to the location of the violation. expected: Description of expected type or value. found: Description of actual type or value found. kind: Category of violation from TypeViolationKind.

Examples

```python violation = TypeViolation(

path=”user.address.zipcode”, expected=”string of 5 digits”, found=“‘ABC123’”, kind=TypeViolationKind.INVALID_VALUE

)

__str__()[source]

Generate human-readable representation of the violation.

Returns:

Formatted string with violation details including path, expected value, found value, and violation kind.

Return type:

str

expected: str
found: str
kind: TypeViolationKind
path: str
class type_forge.validators.TypeViolation[source]

Immutable record of a type violation with path tracking.

Provides a structured representation of a type violation with context information for precise error reporting and diagnosis. The frozen dataclass ensures immutability for safer error handling.

Attributes

path: JSON path to the location of the violation. expected: Description of expected type or value. found: Description of actual type or value found. kind: Category of violation from TypeViolationKind.

Examples

```python violation = TypeViolation(

path=”user.address.zipcode”, expected=”string of 5 digits”, found=“‘ABC123’”, kind=TypeViolationKind.INVALID_VALUE

)

__str__()[source]

Generate human-readable representation of the violation.

Returns:

Formatted string with violation details including path, expected value, found value, and violation kind.

Return type:

str

expected: str
found: str
kind: TypeViolationKind
path: str
class type_forge.validators.TypeViolationKind(*args, **kwds)[source]

Bases: enum.Enum

Enumeration of possible type violation categories.

Provides a structured taxonomy of type violations for precise error categorization and handling.

Attributes

WRONG_TYPE: Value has incorrect type. MISSING_KEY: Required key is absent. INVALID_VALUE: Value fails validation constraints. SCHEMA_MISMATCH: Value structure doesn’t match schema. CONVERSION_ERROR: Type conversion failed.

Examples

```python if isinstance(value, str):

return TypeViolationKind.WRONG_TYPE

```

__str__()[source]

Returns:

The string value of the enumeration.

Return type:

str

CONVERSION_ERROR = 'conversion_error'
INVALID_VALUE = 'invalid_value'
MISSING_KEY = 'missing_key'
SCHEMA_MISMATCH = 'schema_mismatch'
WRONG_TYPE = 'wrong_type'

class type_forge.validators.ValidationIssue(severity, message, path=None, context=None)[source]

Detailed representation of a validation issue with context and severity.

This class encapsulates information about a validation issue, including its severity, location, message, and contextual information for debugging and correction.

Attributes

severity (ValidationSeverity): The severity level of the issue message (str): Human-readable description of the issue path (Optional[str]): Path to the location of the issue (e.g., “user.address.city”) context (Dict[str, object]): Additional contextual information about the issue

Examples

>>> issue = ValidationIssue(ValidationSeverity.ERROR, "Invalid email format")
>>> issue.severity.name
'ERROR'
>>> issue.message
'Invalid email format'
>>> detailed = ValidationIssue(
...     ValidationSeverity.WARNING,
...     "Value outside recommended range",
...     path="settings.timeout",
...     context={"value": 120, "recommended_max": 60}
... )
>>> detailed.path
'settings.timeout'

Initialize a ValidationIssue.

Parameters:

  • severity (type_forge.typing.definitions.ValidationSeverity) – The severity level of the issue

  • message (str) – Human-readable description of the issue

  • path (Optional[str]) – Path to the location of the issue (e.g., “user.address.city”)

  • context (Optional[Dict[str, object]]) – Additional contextual information about the issue

__str__()[source]

String representation of the validation issue.

Returns:

Formatted description of the issue

Return type:

str

Examples

>>> str(ValidationIssue(ValidationSeverity.ERROR, "Invalid data"))
'ERROR: Invalid data'
>>> str(ValidationIssue(ValidationSeverity.WARNING, "Unusual value", path="config.timeout"))
'WARNING at config.timeout: Unusual value'
is_blocker()[source]

Check if this issue should block operation.

Returns:

True if this issue should prevent operation

Return type:

bool

Examples

>>> issue = ValidationIssue(ValidationSeverity.FATAL, "Security violation")
>>> issue.is_blocker()
True
>>> warning = ValidationIssue(ValidationSeverity.ERROR, "Data inconsistency")
>>> warning.is_blocker()
False

Check if this issue is an error.

True if this is an error or fatal issue

bool

>>> issue.is_error()
True
>>> warning = ValidationIssue(ValidationSeverity.WARNING, "Unusual value")
>>> warning.is_error()
False

class type_forge.validators.ValidationReport[source]

Comprehensive report of validation results including all issues found.

This class collects and organizes validation issues, providing methods to query and analyze validation results in detail.

Attributes

issues (List[ValidationIssue]): List of all validation issues found

Examples

>>> report = ValidationReport()
>>> report.add_error("Invalid email")
>>> report.add_warning("Name unusually short", path="user.name")
>>> report.is_valid()
False
>>> report.has_warnings()
True
>>> len(report.get_issues())
2

Initialize an empty ValidationReport.

__bool__()[source]

Boolean evaluation of validation success.

Returns:

True if validation passed (no errors), False otherwise

Return type:

bool

Examples

>>> report = ValidationReport()
>>> bool(report)
True
>>> report.add_error("Problem found")
>>> bool(report)
False
__str__()[source]

String representation of the validation report.

Returns:

Summary of validation results

Return type:

str

Examples

>>> report = ValidationReport()
>>> str(report)
'Validation passed with 0 issues'
>>> report.add_error("Problem 1")
>>> report.add_warning("Minor issue")
>>> str(report)
'Validation failed with 2 issues (1 errors, 1 warnings)'
add_error(message, path=None, context=None)[source]

Add an error issue to the report.

Parameters:

  • message (str) – Description of the error

  • path (Optional[str], optional) – Path to the location of the error. Defaults to None.

  • context (Optional[Dict[str, object]], optional) – Additional contextual information. Defaults to None.

Return type:

None

Examples

>>> report = ValidationReport()
>>> report.add_error("Invalid email format", path="user.email")
>>> report.issues[0].severity
<ValidationSeverity.ERROR: 'error'>

Add an informational issue to the report.

Parameters:

  • path (Optional[str], optional) – Path related to the information. Defaults to None.

  • context (Optional[Dict[str, object]], optional) – Additional contextual information. Defaults to None.

None

  • path (Optional[str], optional) – Path to the location of the warning. Defaults to None.

can_proceed()[source]

Check if operation can proceed despite validation issues.

Returns:

True if there are no blocking issues, False otherwise

Return type:

bool

Examples

>>> report = ValidationReport()
>>> report.add_error("Non-fatal issue")
>>> report.can_proceed()  # Regular errors don't block
True
>>> report.add_issue(ValidationIssue(ValidationSeverity.FATAL, "Security violation"))
>>> report.can_proceed()
False
get_errors()[source]

Get all error issues (ERROR and FATAL).

Returns:

List of error issues

Return type:

List[ValidationIssue]

Examples

>>> report = ValidationReport()
>>> report.add_error("Error 1")
>>> report.add_issue(ValidationIssue(ValidationSeverity.FATAL, "Fatal error"))
>>> report.add_warning("Warning 1")
>>> len(report.get_errors())
2
get_issues(severity=None)[source]

Get validation issues, optionally filtered by severity.

Parameters:

severity (Optional[ValidationSeverity], optional) – If provided, only return issues of this severity. Defaults to None.

Returns:

List of matching issues

Return type:

List[ValidationIssue]

Examples

>>> report = ValidationReport()
>>> report.add_error("Error 1")
>>> report.add_warning("Warning 1")
>>> report.add_info("Info message")
>>> len(report.get_issues())
3
>>> len(report.get_issues(ValidationSeverity.ERROR))
1

List[ValidationIssue]

>>> report.add_error("Error 1")
>>> len(report.get_warnings())
2

>>> report.has_warnings()

is_valid()[source]

Check if the validation passed with no errors.

Returns:

True if no errors were found, False otherwise

Return type:

bool

Examples

>>> report = ValidationReport()
>>> report.is_valid()
True
>>> report.add_warning("Minor issue")
>>> report.is_valid()  # Warnings don't invalidate
True
>>> report.add_error("Serious problem")
>>> report.is_valid()
False
issues: List[ValidationIssue] = []
class type_forge.validators.ValidationResult[source]

Bases: Generic[type_forge.typing.definitions.T]

Result of type validation with possible conversion.

This class encapsulates the outcome of a validation operation, including whether validation passed, any violations that occurred, and an optional converted value that maintains its type through generic constraints.

The ValidationResult maintains type safety through covariant generics, ensuring that type information flows correctly through validation chains and transformations. It acts as both a container for validation status and a monad-like structure that can be composed and transformed while preserving the validation context.

Attributes

valid (bool): Boolean indicating if validation succeeded violations (List[TypeViolation]): List of specific type violations encountered converted_value (Optional[T]): Optional transformed value that maintains

its type through generics

Examples

>>> result = ValidationResult[int](valid=True, converted_value=42)
>>> bool(result)
True
>>> result.with_converted_value("string")
ValidationResult(valid=True, violations=[], converted_value='string')
__bool__()[source]

Boolean conversion returns validation status.

Allows ValidationResult objects to be used directly in boolean contexts for streamlined conditional logic, implementing the “errors as values” pattern in an elegant, composable way.

Returns:

True if validation passed, False otherwise

Return type:

bool

merge(other)[source]

Merge another validation result into this one.

This maintains the type of the original result while incorporating the validation status and violations from another result. The converted value remains that of the original result, preserving type integrity.

This method enables recursive composition of validation results, allowing complex validation logic to be built from simpler components while maintaining full type safety.

Parameters:

other (ValidationResult[object]) – Another validation result to merge with this one

Returns:

Self with merged validation status and violations

Return type:

ValidationResult[T]

with_converted_value(value)[source]

Create a new ValidationResult with the same validation status but a different value.

This method preserves the validation state while transforming the result to contain a new value of potentially different type, properly maintaining type safety through generics. This enables validation pipelines that transform data while maintaining error context.

The implementation follows the principle of “Pure Core, Effects at Edges” by returning a new instance rather than modifying the current one, maintaining immutability for better compositional properties.

Parameters:

value (S) – The converted value to set

Returns:

A new ValidationResult with the same validation status but different value

Return type:

ValidationResult[S]

converted_value: type_forge.typing.definitions.T | None = None
valid: bool
violations: List[type_forge.core.exceptions.TypeViolation] = []

class type_forge.validators.ValidatorFactory[source]

Factory class for creating validators dynamically with type safety.

This class provides static methods for creating various types of validators and performing validation operations with comprehensive error reporting.

The factory pattern enables consistent validator creation with proper configuration and composition, supporting both simple and complex validation scenarios.

static _get_type_name(typ)[source]

Get a human-readable name for a type or type collection.

Parameters:

typ (object) – A type, tuple of types, or list/sequence of types

Returns:

A string representation of the type(s)

Return type:

str

static _try_convert(value, target_type)[source]

Try to convert a value to the target type.

Parameters:

  • value (object) – Value to convert

  • target_type (Type[V]) – Type to convert to

Returns:

Converted value or None if conversion failed

Return type:

Optional[V]

Note

This is an internal method used by validate_type.

static create_validator(validator_type, **kwargs)[source]

Creates a validator based on the specified type.

Parameters:

  • validator_type (str) – The type of validator to create. Must be one of the supported validator types (‘basic’, ‘composite’).

  • **kwargs (Dict[str, object]) – Additional parameters for the validator. Passed directly to the validator constructor.

Returns:

An instance of the requested validator.

Raises:

ValueError – If the validator type is unknown.

Return type:

Callable[[object], bool]

Examples

>>> validator = ValidatorFactory.create_validator('basic')
>>> validator(42)
True
static validate_dict(value, schema, path='$', convert=False, require_all_keys=True)[source]

Validate that a dictionary conforms to a schema.

Parameters:

  • value (object) – Dictionary to validate

  • schema (type_forge.typing.hints.DictSchemaT) – Schema defining expected types for keys

  • path (str) – Current path for error reporting

  • convert (bool) – Whether to attempt type conversion

  • require_all_keys (bool) – Whether all schema keys must be present

Returns:

ValidationResult with validation status and converted dict if applicable

Return type:

type_forge.core.base.ValidationResult[Dict[str, object]]

Examples

>>> schema = {"name": str, "age": int}
>>> data = {"name": "Alice", "age": 30}
>>> result = ValidatorFactory.validate_dict(data, schema)
>>> result.valid
True

>>> data = {"name": "Bob"}  # Missing 'age'
>>> result = ValidatorFactory.validate_dict(data, schema)
>>> result.valid
False
static validate_recursive(value, schema, path='$', convert=False)[source]

Recursively validate a value against a schema of arbitrary complexity.

Parameters:

  • value (object) – Value to validate

  • schema (type_forge.typing.hints.SchemaTypeT) – Schema to validate against (dict, list/sequence, or type)

  • path (str) – Current path for error reporting

  • convert (bool) – Whether to attempt type conversion

Returns:

ValidationResult with validation status and details

Return type:

type_forge.core.base.ValidationResult[object]

Examples

>>> schema = {"name": str, "age": int}
>>> data = {"name": "Alice", "age": 30}
>>> result = ValidatorFactory.validate_recursive(data, schema)
>>> result.valid
True

>>> data = {"name": "Alice", "age": "30"}
>>> result = ValidatorFactory.validate_recursive(data, schema, convert=True)
>>> result.valid
True
>>> result.converted_value
{'name': 'Alice', 'age': 30}
static validate_type(value, expected_type, path='$', convert=False)[source]

Validate that a value matches the expected type recursively.

Parameters:

  • value (object) – The value to check

  • expected_type (Union[Type[type_forge.typing.hints.T], Sequence[Type[object]]]) – Type or types to check against

  • path (str) – Current path in the validation (for error reporting)

  • convert (bool) – Whether to attempt conversion to the expected type

Returns:

ValidationResult with validation status and details

Return type:

type_forge.core.base.ValidationResult[type_forge.typing.hints.T]

Examples

>>> result = ValidatorFactory.validate_type(42, int)
>>> result.valid
True

>>> result = ValidatorFactory.validate_type("42", int, convert=True)
>>> result.valid
True
>>> result.converted_value
42
type_forge.validators.are_types_compatible(source_type, target_type)[source]

Check if two types are compatible for conversion or assignment.

Determines whether values of the source type can generally be converted to the target type without errors.

Parameters:

  • source_type (Type[object]) – The source type to check from

  • target_type (Type[object]) – The target type to check compatibility with

Returns:

True if the types are compatible, False otherwise

Return type:

bool

Examples

>>> are_types_compatible(int, float)
True
>>> are_types_compatible(float, int)
True
>>> are_types_compatible(list, tuple)
True
>>> are_types_compatible(dict, list)
False

Note

This evaluates type compatibility at a general level without considering specific value constraints.

type_forge.validators.has_attributes(obj, *attributes)[source]

Check if an object has all the specified attributes.

Parameters:

  • obj (object) – The object to check

  • *attributes (str) – Attribute names to look for

Returns:

True if object has all attributes, False otherwise

Return type:

bool

Examples

>>> has_attributes([], "append", "extend")
True
>>> has_attributes({}, "update", "missing_attr")
False
>>> has_attributes("string", "upper", "lower")
True
>>> has_attributes(None, "any_attr")
False

Note

This checks for attribute existence, not their values or callability.

type_forge.validators.is_callable(value)[source]

Check if a value is callable (function, method, callable object).

Determines whether an object can be called like a function.

Parameters:

value (object) – The value to check

Returns:

True if the value is callable, False otherwise

Return type:

bool

Examples

>>> is_callable(lambda x: x)
True
>>> is_callable(print)
True
>>> is_callable("not_callable")
False
>>> is_callable(None)
False

Note

This is a type-safe wrapper around the built-in callable() function.

type_forge.validators.is_collection(value)[source]

Check if a value is a collection (list, tuple, set, dict, etc.).

Determines whether a value is a collection type that can contain multiple elements, excluding strings and bytes which are sequence types but not typically treated as collections.

Parameters:

value (object) – The value to check

Returns:

True if the value is a collection, False otherwise

Return type:

bool

Examples

>>> is_collection([1, 2, 3])
True
>>> is_collection((1, 2, 3))
True
>>> is_collection({"a": 1})
True
>>> is_collection("string")  # Strings are not considered collections
False
>>> is_collection(42)
False

Note

Strings and bytes are not considered collections despite being sequences.

type_forge.validators.is_compatible_with_type(value, target_type)[source]

Check if a value can be converted to a target type without errors.

Determines whether a value can be safely converted to the specified type without raising exceptions, allowing for type conversion safety checks.

Parameters:

  • value (object) – The value to check

  • target_type (Type[type_forge.typing.variables.T]) – The target type to check compatibility with

Returns:

True if the value can be safely converted, False otherwise

Return type:

bool

Examples

>>> is_compatible_with_type("123", int)
True
>>> is_compatible_with_type("hello", int)
False
>>> is_compatible_with_type(42, str)
True
>>> is_compatible_with_type([1, 2, 3], tuple)
True

Note

This performs actual conversion attempts and catches exceptions, making it suitable for runtime type compatibility checking.

type_forge.validators.is_function(obj)[source]

Check if an object is a function.

Determines whether an object is a function (not a method or builtin).

Parameters:

obj (object) – The object to check

Returns:

True if the object is a function, False otherwise

Return type:

bool

Examples

>>> def example_function(): pass
>>> is_function(example_function)
True
>>> is_function(len)
False
>>> class Example:
...     def method(self): pass
>>> obj = Example()
>>> is_function(obj.method)
False
>>> is_function(lambda x: x)
True

Note

This identifies pure functions, not methods or built-in functions.

type_forge.validators.is_in_range(value, min_value, max_value)[source]

Check if an integer is within a specified range.

Parameters:

  • value (int)

  • min_value (int)

  • max_value (int)

Return type:

bool

type_forge.validators.is_instance_of_any(value, types)[source]

Check if a value is an instance of any of the specified types.

Determines whether the value is an instance of at least one of the types in the provided tuple.

Parameters:

  • value (object) – The value to check

  • types (Tuple[Type[object], Ellipsis]) – Tuple of types to check against

Returns:

True if value is an instance of any type in types, False otherwise

Return type:

bool

Examples

>>> is_instance_of_any(42, (str, int, float))
True
>>> is_instance_of_any("hello", (list, tuple, dict))
False
>>> is_instance_of_any(None, (str, int, type(None)))
True
>>> is_instance_of_any([], (list, tuple))
True

Note

More efficient than multiple isinstance() calls when checking against many types.

type_forge.validators.is_method(obj)[source]

Check if an object is a method.

Determines whether an object is a method bound to a class instance.

Parameters:

obj (object) – The object to check

Returns:

True if the object is a method, False otherwise

Return type:

bool

Examples

>>> class Example:
...     def method(self): pass
...     @classmethod
...     def class_method(cls): pass
...     @staticmethod
...     def static_method(): pass
>>> obj = Example()
>>> is_method(obj.method)
True
>>> is_method(Example.method)
False
>>> is_method(obj.class_method)
True
>>> is_method(obj.static_method)
False

Note

This distinguishes between bound methods and regular functions.

type_forge.validators.is_non_empty_string(value)[source]

Verify if a value is a non-empty string.

Performs type checking and emptiness validation in a single operation with maximum efficiency.

Parameters:

value (object) – The value to validate. Can be any Python object.

Returns:

True if the value is a non-empty string, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

Examples

>>> is_non_empty_string("hello")
True
>>> is_non_empty_string("")
False
>>> is_non_empty_string(123)
False
>>> is_non_empty_string(None)
False

Note

This function uses isinstance for type checking rather than type() to properly handle inheritance relationships.

Check if a string is not empty.

Parameters:

value (str)

Return type:

bool

type_forge.validators.is_numeric(value)[source]

Check if a value is numeric (int, float, complex, or numeric subclass).

Determines whether a value is of a numeric type, handling both built-in numeric types and numbers.Number subclasses.

Parameters:

value (object) – The value to check

Returns:

True if the value is numeric, False otherwise

Return type:

bool

Examples

>>> is_numeric(42)
True
>>> is_numeric(3.14)
True
>>> is_numeric(1+2j)
True
>>> is_numeric("42")
False
>>> is_numeric(None)
False

Note

This function considers all subclasses of numbers.Number as numeric.

type_forge.validators.is_protocol_instance(obj, protocol)[source]

Check if an object satisfies a Protocol interface.

Safely determines if an object implements all the methods and attributes required by a Protocol, with proper handling of runtime Protocol checking.

Parameters:

  • obj (object) – Object to check

  • protocol (Type[object]) – Protocol to check against

Returns:

True if the object satisfies the protocol, False otherwise

Return type:

bool

Examples

>>> from typing import Protocol
>>> class SupportsLen(Protocol):
...     def __len__(self) -> int: ...
>>> is_protocol_instance([1, 2, 3], SupportsLen)
True
>>> is_protocol_instance(42, SupportsLen)
False

Note

Works with both @runtime_checkable Protocols and regular Protocols. For non-runtime-checkable protocols, uses attribute inspection.

type_forge.validators.is_subclass_safe(cls, parent)[source]

Safely check if a class is a subclass of another class.

Performs an issubclass check that won’t raise TypeError if the first argument is not a class, unlike the built-in issubclass function.

Parameters:

  • cls (object) – The potential subclass to check

  • parent (type_forge.typing.aliases.ParentSpecType[object]) – The parent class(es) to check against

Returns:

True if cls is a subclass of parent, False otherwise

Return type:

bool

Examples

>>> is_subclass_safe(str, object)
True
>>> is_subclass_safe("not_a_class", object)
False
>>> is_subclass_safe(dict, (list, tuple))
False
>>> is_subclass_safe(list, (list, tuple))
True
>>> is_subclass_safe(None, object)
False

Note

This is a safer version of the built-in issubclass() function that won’t raise TypeError for non-class objects.

type_forge.validators.is_valid_identifier(name)[source]

Check if a string is a valid Python identifier.

Validates that a string can be used as a Python variable, function, or class name according to Python syntax rules.

Parameters:

name (str) – The string to check

Returns:

True if the string is a valid Python identifier, False otherwise

Return type:

bool

Examples

>>> is_valid_identifier("valid_name")
True
>>> is_valid_identifier("123invalid")
False
>>> is_valid_identifier("also-invalid")
False
>>> is_valid_identifier("")
False
>>> is_valid_identifier("_private")
True

Note

A valid identifier starts with a letter or underscore and contains only letters, numbers, and underscores.

type_forge.validators.is_valid_length(value, min_length=None, max_length=None)[source]

Check if a collection has a valid length.

Parameters:

  • value (Collection[Any]) – The collection to check

  • min_length (Optional[int]) – Minimum allowed length (inclusive), or None for no minimum

  • max_length (Optional[int]) – Maximum allowed length (inclusive), or None for no maximum

Returns:

True if the length is valid, False otherwise

Return type:

bool

type_forge.validators.DictSchemaT[source]

Dictionary schema mapping string keys to schema types.

This represents object structures with string keys mapping to schema-defined values, enabling the definition of complex nested objects.

Examples

>>> person_schema: DictSchemaT = {"name": str, "age": int}
>>> nested_schema: DictSchemaT = {"user": {"id": int, "name": str}}
type_forge.validators.ParentSpecType[source]

Parent class specification supporting single class or tuple of classes.

Used for inheritance definitions and interface specifications.

type_forge.validators.SchemaTypeT[source]

A schema type definition that can recursively represent any data structure.

This type allows the definition of complex nested structures with full type safety, supporting simple types, unions of types, dictionary schemas, and list schemas.

Examples

>>> # Simple type schema
>>> int_schema: SchemaTypeT = int
>>>
>>> # Union type schema (alternative types)
>>> union_schema: SchemaTypeT = (int, str)
>>>
>>> # Dictionary schema (nested object)
>>> dict_schema: SchemaTypeT = {"name": str, "age": int}
>>>
>>> # List schema (array of integers)
>>> list_schema: SchemaTypeT = [int]
